cnd6:2.1: "Master, let me ask you, please tell me this": "I ask," I ask of you; I beg you;
cnd6:2.2: please make me clear; please tell me. "The Blessed One" is synonymous with
cnd6:2.3: respect. In addition, the "greed breaker" is the Blessed One; the "sickness
cnd6:2.4: destroyer" is the Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed conceit" is the
cnd6:2.5: Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed the thorns" is the Blessed One; "the one
cnd6:2.6: who has destroyed the pollutants" is Blessed One; "the one who has ended" is the
cnd6:2.7: Blessed One; "the one who has practiced the body, the precepts, the mind, and
cnd6:2.8: the wisdom" is the Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is close to the woods, wild
cnd6:2.9: forests, and border dwellings (sitting place), where speaking is lessened, it is
cnd6:2.10: quiet, away from the human atmosphere, alone, and suitable for sitting alone" is
cnd6:2.11: the Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is the one who divides clothes, food,
cnd6:2.12: shelter, the needs of patients, and medical necessities"; or "the Blessed One is
cnd6:2.13: the one who has the taste of righteousness, the taste of Dhamma, the taste of
cnd6:2.14: liberation, the increased precepts, the mind, and the wisdom"; or "the Blessed
cnd6:2.15: One is the four types of jhāna, the four immeasurables, the four formlessness,
cnd6:2.16: etc., the one who divides is the Blessed One"; or the Blessed One is the one who
cnd6:2.17: has the eighth liberation, the eight victories, the ninth dwelling place, etc.;
cnd6:2.18: or the Blessed One is the practice of ten thoughts, (ten) abidings, the one who
cnd6:2.19: (observes) the in and out of breath; the one who is purely divided is the
cnd6:2.20: Blessed One; or the Blessed One divides the four mindfulness, the four
cnd6:2.21: righteousness, the four divine bases (iddhipāda), the five faculties, the five
cnd6:2.22: powers, the seven enlightenment factors, and the eight branches of the holy
cnd6:2.23: path; or the Blessed One is ten Tathāgata, four fearlessness, four unobstructed
cnd6:2.24: solutions, six supernatural powers and the six enlightenment methods. "Blessed
cnd6:2.25: One," this name is not given by the mother; not given by the father; not given
cnd6:2.26: by brothers; not given by sisters; not given by friends; not given by relatives;
cnd6:2.27: not given by Samaṇas or Brāhmaṇas; not given by heaven; it is ultimate
cnd6:2.28: liberation; the establishment (of the pseudonym) for the acquisition and
cnd6:2.29: testimony of the Buddha, the Blessed One, under the Bodhi tree, and all
cnd6:2.30: knowledge and wisdom, that is, the Blessed One.
cnd6:3.1: "[Venerable Dhotaka like this]": "Like this," "Like this," the continuation of
cnd6:3.2: the sentences, the connection of the words, the completion of the sentences, the
cnd6:3.3: combination of words, this is the order of the sentence, which is "like this."
cnd6:3.4: "Venerable," this is a synonym of love, respect, and obedience. "Dhotaka," the
cnd6:3.5: name, title, security of the Brāhmaṇa, title, word, phrase.
cnd6:4.1: "Great rishi! I look forward to your words": Your words, ways of speaking,
cnd6:4.2: teaching, teaching, admonition, I expect, I hope, I pray. "Great rishi," why is
cnd6:4.3: the Blessed One the Great rishi? The "seekers, and pursuers of the great
cnd6:4.4: precepts" are the great rishis. ...of the great concentration..., ...of the
cnd6:4.5: great liberation aggregate..., "the seeker and pursuer of the great liberation
cnd6:4.6: of wisdom and insight" is the great rishi; the fragments gathered by the
cnd6:4.7: dark..., the destruction of the great upside down..., the pulling out of the big
cnd6:4.8: arrow of thirst..., the unraveling of the accumulation of sight..., the lifting
cnd6:4.9: of the big conceit flag, ...the calming of the great work..., the calming of the
cnd6:4.10: big torrent..., the laying down of the heavy burden..., the severance of the
cnd6:4.11: cycle of the great reincarnation..., the disappearance of the great heat..., the
cnd6:4.12: cessation of the great heat..., "the seeker and the pursuer who lifts the flag
cnd6:4.13: of Dhamma in his heart" is the great rishi; the great minds..., the great
cnd6:4.14: exertion..., the great divine bases..., the great roots..., the power..., the
cnd6:4.15: great enlightenment branches..., the big eight branches of the holy path...,
cnd6:4.16: "the immortality of the great supreme benefit, the seeker of Nibbāna, the
cnd6:4.17: pursuer" is great rishi; "sought, pursued, and searched for by powerful beings:
cnd6:4.18: Where is the Buddha? Where is the Blessed One? Where is the god among the gods?
cnd6:4.19: Where is the bull king among people?" Such is the great rishi. "The highest
cnd6:4.20: Dhamma," the highest Dhamma is called non-living, Nibbāna, that is the cessation
cnd6:4.21: of all actions, the cessation of all attachments, the cessation of craving,
cnd6:5.1: "After hearing your words": Your speech, language, teachings admonitions; after
cnd6:5.2: hearing, after grasping, after understanding, after discriminating.
cnd6:6.1: "You should learn for your own Nibbāna": There are three types of learning: to
cnd6:6.2: learn to increase precepts, to learn to increase mind, and to also learn to
cnd6:7.1: What is meant by "to increase precepts?" Here, the bhikkhu is a preceptor who
cnd6:7.2: lives in the protection of self-control of the Pātimokkha. He has sufficient
cnd6:7.3: righteousness and state of affairs. He sees the horror in minor sins and learns
cnd6:7.4: after accepting from a teacher. Small precepts aggregate and large precept
cnd6:7.5: aggregates are the foundation of abstinence, the (self) inhibition of behavior,
cnd6:7.6: the entrance of self-control, the uppermost of good dhamma, etc., this is to
cnd6:8.1: What is meant by "to increase mind?" Here, the bhikkhu starts from the desire to
cnd6:8.2: escape... (omitted) the first jhāna..., the second jhāna..., the third jhāna...,
cnd6:8.3: after entering, he lives in the fourth jhāna (neither suffering or joyous, from
cnd6:8.4: calm and chanting), this is "to learn to increase mind."
cnd6:9.1: What is learning to increase wisdom? Here, the bhikkhu is a wise person,
cnd6:9.2: possessing the knowledge of arising and passing away; the holy, insight, and the
cnd6:9.3: complete extinction of suffering is (the wisdom), he truthfully knows "This is
cnd6:9.4: suffering. ...(omitted)" "this is hard work."... "this is the path that leads to
cnd6:9.5: suffering"... "these are troubles"... "this is the set of troubles"... "this is
cnd6:9.6: annoyance"... "this is the path leading to troubles;" this is the addition of
cnd6:9.7: wisdom. These three learnings, they learn when they face (note); they learn when
cnd6:9.8: they know; they learn when they see (; when they learn with introspection); they
cnd6:9.9: learn when the mind is established (in a decision); they learn when faith
cnd6:9.10: prevails; they learn with vigor and hard work; when mindfulness arises, they
cnd6:9.11: learn; when mind is set (focused) they learn; when wisdom is learned, they
cnd6:9.12: learn; when they are proved to have known, they learn; they learn through
cnd6:9.13: renunciation; they learn when they practice; they practice well, and sustain
cnd6:9.14: when they are testified, then they go on. For this reason they are called
cnd6:9.15: learning. "Everyone" is the multitude. These learned practitioners are the
cnd6:10.1: "For your own Nibbāna," to extinguish your own greed, ...anger, ..ignorance,
cnd6:10.2: ...(omitted); to calm, silence, extinguish, cut off, and cease all unwholesome
cnd6:10.3: practices, you should learn to increase precepts, you learn to increase mind,
cnd6:10.4: and you should learn to increase wisdom. These three learnings should be studied
cnd6:10.5: when directed towards (noting); when known they should be learned; when seen...
cnd6:10.6: (omitted); when introspecting...; and being careful to establish (a decision),
cnd6:10.7: you should learn; you should learn when you win by faith; you should learn when
cnd6:10.8: you have energetic effort; you should learn when mindfulness arises; you should
cnd6:10.9: learn with mindfulness; you should learn when you know with wisdom; we should
cnd6:10.10: learn when we can testify; we should learn when we can know; we should learn
cnd6:10.11: when we should be renounced; we should learn when we should be practiced as
cnd6:10.12: testimony; [Ps.1,41] learning should be practiced, should be carried out well,
cnd6:10.13: one should go on after accepting.
cnd6:11.2: If that is the case, please be enthusiastic,
cnd6:11.5: You should learn for your own Nibbāna.
cnd6:11.7: If that is the case, please be enthusiastic,
cnd6:11.10: You should learn for your own Nibbāna.
cnd6:11.12: If that is the case, please be enthusiastic,

cnd6:11.22: If that is the case, please be enthusiastic,
cnd6:11.25: You should learn for your own Nibbāna.
cnd6:12.1: "If that's the case, please be enthusiastic": Please be enthusiastic, please be
cnd6:12.2: brave, please be zealous, please have fortitude, please be firm, please be
cnd6:12.3: vigorous; and may you make it happen, make it arise, make it fully produced,
cnd6:12.4: make it appear, make it live.
cnd6:14.1: "Wise and mindful here": "Here," belonging to this view, to this liking, to this
cnd6:14.2: inclination, in this attachment, in this Dhamma; in this teaching; in this
cnd6:14.3: Brahma, in the teachings of this master, in this individual, in this human
cnd6:14.4: world. "Wise," the concious, the enlightened, the discriminating, the wise.
cnd6:15.1: "Mindful," Mindful in four ways: when practicing mindfulness on the body, when
cnd6:15.2: practicing mindfulness on perception, when watching the mind in the heart, when
cnd6:15.3: the practice is in line with the teachings, it is mindful.
cnd6:16.1: And again in four ways: the state of avoiding non-mind, the state of the Dhamma
cnd6:16.2: that should be done to the mind, the state of the Dhamma that is obstructed by
cnd6:16.3: the mind, the state of the mindfulness factor (phase) not being forgotten.
cnd6:17.1: And again in four ways: the state of possessing mindfulness, the state of
cnd6:17.2: abiding in mindfulness, the state of experiencing mindfulness, and the state of
cnd6:18.1: And again in four ways: with the state of being mindful as the object of
cnd6:18.2: mindfulness, the quiet state as the object, the calm state as the object, the
cnd6:18.3: state of silence; the recollection of the Buddha, the recollection of the
cnd6:18.4: Dhamma, the recollection of the Saṅgha, the precepts, the alms, of the mind;
cnd6:18.5: mindfulness of the in and out breath, of death, of the body, of silence; all
cnd6:18.6: mindfulness, free-mindfulness..., the path without a fork, are called
cnd6:18.7: mindfulness. Having been fully possessed, reaching fully, possessing, arriving,
cnd6:18.8: with this thought, he is called mindful.
cnd6:20.1: "You should learn for your own Nibbāna": ....
cnd6:21.1: <em>32 : (Dhotaka:) I see a Brāhmaṇa owning nothing
cnd6:21.2: In the world of heaven and the world of man,
cnd6:21.3: I salute you, all-seeing one, Sakyamuni!
cnd6:21.5: <em>32 : (Dhotaka:) I see a Brāhmaṇa owning nothing
cnd6:21.6: In the world of heaven and the world of man,
cnd6:21.7: I salute you, all-seeing one, Sakyamuni!

cnd6:21.10: In the world of heaven and the world of man,

cnd6:21.13: <em>32 : (Dhotaka:) I see a Brāhmaṇa owning nothing
cnd6:21.14: In the world of heaven and the world of man,
cnd6:21.15: I salute you, all-seeing one, Sakyamuni!
cnd6:22.1: "I see, in heaven and the world of man": "Heaven," there are three types of
cnd6:22.2: heaven: general (secular, worldly) heaven, rebirth heaven, and pure heaven. What
cnd6:22.3: is secular heaven? Kings and princes and queens are called secular heavens. What
cnd6:22.4: is the rebirth heaven? The four great god kings, the realm of the thirty-three
cnd6:22.5: gods, Tusita heaven, fashioned heaven, all Brahma heavens, and all the heavens
cnd6:22.6: above that are called rebirth heavens. What is pure heaven? The troubles of the
cnd6:22.7: disciples of the Tathāgata, Arahants, and Paccekabuddhas, have been exhausted,
cnd6:22.8: this is called pure heavens. The Blessed One is of the general heaven, the
cnd6:22.9: rebirth heaven, the pure heaven, and the victorious heaven, the heaven among the
cnd6:22.10: heaven, the lion among the lions, the dragon among the dragons, the lord among
cnd6:22.11: the lords, the Muni among the Munis, the king among the kings. "I see in the
cnd6:22.12: heavens and in the world of man": In the world of man and the heavens, I see, I
cnd6:22.13: see the superior heaven, I see the heaven in the heaven; I see, I watch, I
cnd6:23.1: "Brāhmaṇa actors (doers) without possessions": "No," no greed, no hatred,
cnd6:23.2: ignorance, sloth, seeing (views), pollution, evil deeds; any of these, for the
cnd6:23.3: Blessed One, it has been cut off, and the roots have been cut off, just like a
cnd6:23.4: palm tree without roots, becoming non-existent and non-living for the future.
cnd6:23.5: Therefore, the Buddha is called the non-owner. "Brāhmaṇa," the Blessed One is
cnd6:23.6: the one in the state of excluding the seven dhammas: seeing is excluded,
cnd6:23.7: suspicion is excluded, abstinence.., greed..., aversion, ignorance, sloth, and
cnd6:23.8: those evil and unwholesome dhammas are excluded: those that are polluted, there
cnd6:23.9: are again. People who are fearful, who suffer the consequences, and will die in
cnd6:24.7: Like this can be called Brāhmaṇa."
cnd6:25.1: "Actor," walker, doer, dweller, on-goer, guardian, and survivor.
cnd6:26.1: "I respect you, all-seeing one": "You," he addressed the Blessed One. "I
cnd6:26.2: respect," I respect with my body, or I respect with words, or I respect with my
cnd6:26.3: heart, or I respect in intention, or I follow the Dhamma to show respect,
cnd6:26.4: salute. "All-seeing," all-eyes are called the state of all knowing wisdom. The
cnd6:26.5: Blessed One has the state of intelligence, of fully having, entering, fully
cnd6:26.6: entering, sufficiently having, having all the knowledge.
cnd6:27.1: "For him, there is nothing unseen here (in this world),
cnd6:27.2: There is no knowledge that cannot be known,
cnd6:27.3: He proves that everything that exists should be guided by inference,
cnd6:27.4: Because the Tathāgata, like that, is all-eyes."
cnd6:28.1: "Sakyamuni! Please free me from doubts": "Sakyamuni," Sakyamuni is a bhikkhu
cnd6:28.2: from the house of Sakya. This is Sakyamuni. Or, "the rich, the wealthy," this is
cnd6:28.3: also Sakyamuni. For him there are these wealth, namely: trusting wealth,
cnd6:28.4: abstaining from wealth, ashamed of wealth, hearing about wealth, giving wealth,
cnd6:28.5: wisdom wealth, mindfulness of wealth, righteous wealth, divine wealth, root
cnd6:28.6: wealth, strength wealth, enlightenment wealth, Path wealth, Fruit wealth,
cnd6:28.7: Nibbāna wealth, and use these various treasures as the rich, the wealthy. Or,
cnd6:28.8: those who are possible, those who are able, those who flow out all types of
cnd6:28.9: things, those who are sufficient, those who are heroes, those who are brave,
cnd6:28.10: those who are heroic, those who are not timid, those who are not frightened,
cnd6:28.11: those who do not run away, those who have given up fear of fear, those who have
cnd6:28.12: given up terror and fear. "Doubts" are called doubts: doubt of suffering, doubt
cnd6:28.13: of the path leading to suffering, doubt of the future, doubt of the past, doubt
cnd6:28.14: of the future and the past, doubt of causal connections, such doubts,
cnd6:28.15: suspicions, doubtful states, confusion, hesitation, crossroads, inconsistent
cnd6:28.16: grasping, hesitating, incomplete understanding, stiff state, confusion of mind.
cnd6:28.17: "Sakyamuni! Please free me from doubt": Please free me, please release me, pull
cnd6:28.18: me out, please pull me out completely, bring me out of doubt.
cnd6:29.1: <em>33 : (The Blessed One:) I will not be able to liberate, Dhotaka,
cnd6:29.2: Anyone who doubts in the world,
cnd6:29.3: When you know the best Dhamma,
cnd6:29.4: Then you will get through this torrent.
cnd6:29.5: <em>33 : (The Blessed One:) I will not be able to liberate, Dhotaka,
cnd6:29.6: Anyone who doubts in the world,
cnd6:29.7: When you know the best Dhamma,
cnd6:29.8: Then you will get through this torrent.

cnd6:29.10: Anyone who doubts in the world,
cnd6:29.11: When you know the best Dhamma,
cnd6:29.12: Then you will get through this torrent.
cnd6:29.13: <em>33 : (The Blessed One:) I will not be able to liberate, Dhotaka,
cnd6:29.14: Anyone who doubts in the world,
cnd6:29.15: When you know the best Dhamma,
cnd6:29.16: Then you will get through this torrent.
cnd6:30.1: "I will not be able to liberate": I will not be able to release, free, make
cnd6:30.2: liberated, pull out, pull out completely, make to ascend, make to fully ascend,
cnd6:30.3: a being struck by the arrow of doubt. Or, I don't work hard on the unbelievers,
cnd6:30.4: on the unwilling, on the slack, on those with inferior vitality, on the
cnd6:30.5: inactive; I don't do my best, I don't strive, I don't do with valor, I don't
cnd6:30.6: work with enthusiasm, I don't make fortitude, I don't make determination, I
cnd6:30.7: don't make vitality, I don't make it produce, I don't make it appear, I don't
cnd6:30.8: make it fully produced, I don't make it arise, I don't make it give birth to the
cnd6:30.9: teachings of the Dhamma. Or, you don't have any other liberators. Those who can
cnd6:30.10: be liberated use their own fortitude, with their own energy, with their own
cnd6:30.11: striving, with their own brave efforts, with their own power, with their own
cnd6:30.12: human power, with their own human vitality, with their own work, with their own
cnd6:30.13: correct way of doing, following the path, not going the opposite way, the way of
cnd6:30.14: following the Dhamma, and the way of doing the Dhamma, they can be freed.
cnd6:31.1: This was said by the Blessed One: "Cunda! 'I am the one who has fallen into the
cnd6:31.2: quagmire and will pull out the other people who have fallen into the quagmire.'
cnd6:31.3: This is impossible. Cunda! 'I am an unregulated, untrained, non-Nibbāna one. I
cnd6:31.4: will make others tune, train, and attain Nibbāna.' This is impossible." [MN.8]
cnd6:32.1: This is said by the Blessed One: [Dph.12,165]
cnd6:32.2: "He who has done evil, he is polluted,
cnd6:32.3: He who does do not do evil, He come pure,
cnd6:32.4: Purity and impurity are separate, one cannot make the other pure."
cnd6:33.1: This was also said by the Blessed One: "Similarly, Brāhmaṇa, Nibbāna stays and
cnd6:33.2: abides, the path which leads to Nibbāna stays and abides, and my persuasion
cnd6:33.3: (teaching) stays and abides. However, when my disciples are taught and
cnd6:33.4: admonished in this way, some of them reach the ultimate end of Nibbāna, and some
cnd6:33.5: do not reach. Brāhmaṇa, What can I do here? Brāhmaṇa, The Tathāgata is the
cnd6:33.6: guide. [MN.107] The Buddha only told (directed) the way, and when they practice
cnd6:33.7: it by themselves, they could be free."
cnd6:34.1: "Any doubter in the world": A doubter, a person who has doubts, confusion, and
cnd6:34.2: hesitation. "Any (person)," any khattiya, or Brāhmaṇa, or vessa, or sudda, or
cnd6:34.3: layman, or bhikkhu, or heaven, or person. "In the world," in the world of the
cnd6:35.1: "When knowing the most triumphant Dhamma": The highest Dhamma is called
cnd6:35.2: non-living, Nibbāna, which is the cessation of all actions, the cessation of
cnd6:35.3: all attachments, the cessation of craving, greed, extinguishment, and Nibbāna.
cnd6:35.4: Supreme, the first, the most victorious, the extraordinary, the highest, the
cnd6:35.5: most advanced Dhamma; when knowing, distinguishing, understanding, through.
cnd6:36.1: "This way you will get through this torrent": Such a torrent of desire, the
cnd6:36.2: torrent of seeing, the torrent of ignorance, you can get through, you can
cnd6:36.3: surpass, you can you can overcome the torrent.
cnd6:37.1: <em>34 : (Dhotaka:) Brāhmaṇa! I ask, out of compassion,
cnd6:37.2: Teach me the Dhamma of seclusion,
cnd6:37.3: (So that) as the void is not bound,
cnd6:37.4: Here I can walk silently and unrestrained.

cnd6:37.6: Teach me the Dhamma of seclusion,
cnd6:37.7: (So that) as the void is not bound,

cnd6:37.10: Teach me the Dhamma of seclusion,
cnd6:37.11: (So that) as the void is not bound,
cnd6:37.12: Here I can walk silently and unrestrained.

cnd6:37.14: Teach me the Dhamma of seclusion,
cnd6:37.15: (So that) as the void is not bound,
cnd6:37.16: Here I can walk silently and unrestrained.
cnd6:38.1: "Brāhmaṇa! Please teach the commandment out of compassion": Brāhmaṇa, please
cnd6:38.2: teach the commandment; Brāhmaṇa, please help; Brāhmaṇa, please be merciful. "The
cnd6:38.3: compassionate person," The compassionate, the sympathizer, the protector, the
cnd6:39.1: "The Dhamma of seclusion, that I can know": Seclusion Dhamma is called
cnd6:39.2: non-living, Nibbāna, that is the cessation of all actions, the cessation of all
cnd6:39.3: attachments, the extinction of craving, greed, extinction, and Nibbāna. "I can
cnd6:39.4: know," I can know, discern, know for sure, understand, prove, reach, and
cnd6:40.1: "As the void (space) is not bound": As the void is not stuck, not captured, not
cnd6:40.2: bound, not tied to the world, then it is the one who is not stuck, not captured,
cnd6:40.3: and not tied, the one who is not all-bound. (Or,) as the emptiness is not dyed
cnd6:40.4: with carmine, or golden yellow, or indigo, or deep red, then the one who is not
cnd6:40.5: dyed (stained), the one who is not angry, the one who does not change foolishly,
cnd6:40.6: and the one who does not pollute. As the void does not get angry, is not
cnd6:40.7: abusive, does not resist, and is not attacked, this is the one who is not angry,
cnd6:40.8: the one who is not abusive, the one who does not resist, the one who is not
cnd6:40.9: attacked, and the one who does not fight back.
cnd6:41.1: "Here I can walk silently and unrestrainedly": "Here, silently," when you are
cnd6:41.2: here; when you are sitting here; when you are sitting on this seat; when sitting
cnd6:41.3: down among the crowd. Or, just here is silent, calm, cooled, stopped. There are
cnd6:41.4: two types of dependence: the dependence of craving and the dependence of
cnd6:41.5: seeing... (omitted). After the dependence of love has been cut off, and the
cnd6:41.6: dependence of seeing has been cut off, one becomes non-dependent on the eyes,
cnd6:41.7: ...the ear..., the nose, tongue, body, mind, forms, sounds, smells, tastes,
cnd6:41.8: touches, dhammas, family, group, residence, gain, reputation, praise, clothes,
cnd6:41.9: food, dwelling, (patient's needs and medical necessities), the desire realm, the
cnd6:41.10: formed realm, the formless realm, the desire to be, the desire for the formless,
cnd6:41.11: the desire to have, to exist, one aggregate, four aggregates, five aggregates,
cnd6:41.12: past, future, present, what you see, hear, feel, and can perceive; those who do
cnd6:41.13: not adhere to, those who do not fall into, those who do not turn their minds
cnd6:41.14: towards, those who have left, have given up, have been freed, have been
cnd6:41.15: separated from the bondage, living with an unrestrained heart. "Can do" can
cnd6:41.16: live, can act, can go on, can guard, can survive.
cnd6:42.2: I will tell you about the stillness,
cnd6:42.3: Known in (real) life rather than (through) rumor,
cnd6:42.4: Anyone who knows it, living mindfully,
cnd6:42.5: Can cross over love (desire) in the world.
cnd6:42.7: I will tell you about the stillness,
cnd6:42.8: Known in (real) life rather than (through) rumor,
cnd6:42.9: Anyone who knows it, living mindfully,
cnd6:42.10: Can cross over love (desire) in the world.

cnd6:42.14: Anyone who knows it, living mindfully,
cnd6:42.15: Can cross over love (desire) in the world.
cnd6:42.17: I will tell you about the stillness,
cnd6:42.18: Known in (real) life rather than (through) rumor,
cnd6:42.19: Anyone who knows it, living mindfully,
cnd6:42.20: Can cross over love (desire) in the world.
cnd6:42.22: I will tell you about the stillness,
cnd6:42.23: Known in (real) life rather than (through) rumor,
cnd6:42.24: Anyone who knows it, living mindfully,
cnd6:42.25: Can cross over love (desire) in the world.
cnd6:43.1: "I will tell you about the stillness": The stillness of greed, the stillness of
cnd6:43.2: aversion, ...(omitted), the stillness of all unwholesome creations; silence,
cnd6:43.3: cessation; I will tell, announce, say, explain, teach, interpret, build,
cnd6:44.1: "[The Blessed One: 'Dhotaka'] ": "Dhotaka," the World Venerable calls the
cnd6:45.1: "In the current life and not from hearsay": "In the current life," in the seen,
cnd6:45.2: in the known, in the measured, in the made clear: "All actions are
cnd6:45.3: impermanent"... (omitted) "any collection of dhammas is an extinction of
cnd6:45.4: dhammas" means in the Dhamma that is seen (in the current life), in the Dhamma
cnd6:45.5: that is known, in the Dhamma that is measured, in the Dhamma that is made clear;
cnd6:45.6: this is what I will talk about, in the real life. Or, I will tell you about the
cnd6:45.7: suffering which is seen, I will tell you about the collection which is seen, I
cnd6:45.8: will tell you the way which is seen, I will tell you about the extinction of
cnd6:45.9: what is seen, and this is what I will talk about, in the present. Or, in the
cnd6:45.10: life as directly visible, instant, inviting you to see, able to guide, and the
cnd6:45.11: wise should experience it by themselves; this is what I will talk about, in this
cnd6:45.12: life. "Not rumors," not anecdotal, not from hearsay, not from inheritance, not
cnd6:45.13: from scripture, not from logical inference, not from reasoning, not because of
cnd6:45.14: theoretical reflection, not because of an opinion received after reflection, but
cnd6:45.15: by oneself. The known and self-evidenced Dhamma, I will talk about that.
cnd6:46.1: "Anyone who lives mindfully after knowing": After knowing, weighing, judging,
cnd6:46.2: separating, clarifying: "All actions are impermanent" after knowing,
cnd6:46.3: ...(omitted). "Mindful," ...(omitted) he is called mindful. "Living," when you
cnd6:46.4: go, live, act, guard, exist, survive.
cnd6:47.1: "Able to cross through love in the world": "Love" is called craving, which is
cnd6:47.2: greed, ...(omitted) unwholesome roots. "Being in love," what does it mean to be
cnd6:47.3: loving? The "spread" is love, the "broad" is love, the "vast" is love, the
cnd6:47.4: "incorrect" is love, "it forces" is love, "it seizes" is love, "fraud" is love,
cnd6:47.5: "poisonous root" is love, "poisonous fruit" is love, "poison is used" is love;
cnd6:47.6: or, "the vast thirst for love": in form..., sound..., smell..., taste...
cnd6:47.7: (omitted), the material realm, the formless realm, the desire realm, the four
cnd6:47.8: constituents, the five endowments, past, future, now, the enlarged attachments
cnd6:47.9: in the dhammas that are seen, heard, felt, and knowable, are love. "In the
cnd6:47.10: world," in the world of suffering, in the world of humans, (omitted)..., and in
cnd6:47.11: the world of being. "Able to cross the love in the world": "The love in the
cnd6:47.12: world, he can pass through, surpass, pass, transcend, and overcome mindfully"

cnd6:49.1: "I rejoice at that": "That," your words, language, teaching, teaching,
cnd6:49.2: admonition. "I rejoice," I am happy, I wish, I hope, I pray.
cnd6:50.1: "Great rishi! The supreme silence": "Great rishi" ...(omitted). "The supreme
cnd6:50.2: silence," silence is called non-living, Nibbāna, that is the cessation of all
cnd6:51.1: "Anyone who knows the thought after knowing": After knowing... (omitted).
cnd6:52.1: "Able to live through the love in the world": "Love" is called craving...
cnd6:53.2: Anything you know rightly, in the upper, lower and middle four directions,
cnd6:53.3: After knowing that this is the "tie" in the world,
cnd6:53.4: You should not be thirsty for all types of existence.
cnd6:53.6: Anything you know rightly, in the upper, lower and middle four directions,
cnd6:53.7: After knowing that this is the "tie" in the world,
cnd6:53.8: You should not be thirsty for all types of existence.
cnd6:53.10: Anything you know rightly, in the upper, lower and middle four directions,
cnd6:53.11: After knowing that this is the "tie" in the world,
cnd6:53.12: You should not be thirsty for all types of existence.

cnd6:54.1: "Anything you know rightly": Anything you know rightly, what you understand,
cnd6:54.2: what you know, what you know for sure. "Dhotaka," .... "Blessed One," ....
cnd6:55.1: "Upper, lower, and middle four directions": "Up" is the future, "down" is the
cnd6:55.2: past, "middle four" is the present; "up" is the heavenly world, "down" is the
cnd6:55.3: hell world, "middle four" is the world of human beings. Or, "up" is good Dhamma,
cnd6:55.4: "down" is unwholesome Dhamma, "middle four" is non-marked Dhamma; "up" is the
cnd6:55.5: formless realm, "down" is the desire realm, and "middle four" is the physical
cnd6:55.6: realm; "up" means joy, "down" means suffering, "middle four" means neither
cnd6:55.7: suffering nor joy; "up" means above the sole of the foot, "down" means below the
cnd6:55.8: hair, and "middle four" means in the middle.
cnd6:56.1: "After knowing that this is the 'tie' in the world": This is the tie, this is
cnd6:56.2: adhesion, this is binding, this is an obstacle. After knowing, after
cnd6:56.3: understanding, after weighing, after judging, after separating.
cnd6:57.1: "Don't thirst in all types of existence": "Thirst" for love, the thirst for
cnd6:57.2: form, the thirst for sound... (omitted), the thirst for Dhamma. "In all types of
cnd6:57.3: existence," all types of existence in kamma, in the middle, in the desire to be
cnd6:57.4: exist again; in the desire to have, the physical existence; in the physical
cnd6:57.5: existence, the formless existence; in the formless existence, existence again
cnd6:57.6: and again; in repeated coming around, rebirth; in rebirth, individual birth.
cnd6:57.7: Don't be thirsty, don't arouse craving, don't produce desire, don't want thirst,
cnd6:57.8: don't give birth to thirst, give up, drive away, cause it to end, make it go to
cnd6:58.1: At the end of these verses... "The Blessed One is my teacher, I am a disciple."
